## 2. TAX & FISCAL POLICY (5+ Documents)

### 2.1 CORPORATE TAX RATES FOR FINANCIAL SERVICES

**SOURCE_URL:** https://taxsummaries.pwc.com/ghana/corporate/taxes-on-corporate-income
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Ghana
**CATEGORY:** Tax
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Tax Summary
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2024
**CONTENT:**

**General Corporate Income Tax (CIT) Rate:** 25%

**Financial Sector Specific Levies:**

**1. Financial Sector Recovery Levy (FSRL):**
- Applies to: Banks (excluding rural or community banks)
- Rate: **5%** levy on profit before tax
- Purpose: Raise revenue to support financial sector reforms
- **Not an allowable deduction** in calculating chargeable income

**2. Growth and Sustainability Levy (GSL):**
- Effective: May 1, 2023
- Applicable for: Tax years 2023-2028
- Based on: Profits before tax
- Payable quarterly: March 31, June 30, September 30, December 31

**Special Rates:**
- Banks lending to agricultural and leasing sectors: **20%** CIT on income from those businesses

**Other Key Information:**
- No local, state, or provincial government taxes on income
- Capital gains taxed as ordinary income at **25%**

**Summary for Financial Services:**
Banks generally face 25% corporate tax + 5% Financial Sector Recovery Levy on profit before tax = effective rate consideration of 30% (though FSRL not deductible for tax purposes).

---

### 2.2 VAT EXEMPTIONS FOR FINANCIAL SERVICES

**SOURCE_URL:** https://www.ey.com/en_gl/technical/tax-alerts/ghana-s-2024-budget-statement-tax-proposals-passed-into-law
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Ghana
**CATEGORY:** Tax
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Tax Alert
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2024
**CONTENT:**

**Financial Services VAT Status:**

**Exempt from VAT:**
Supply of financial services, **excluding non-life insurance**, is exempt from VAT.

**2024 Critical Change:**
Provision of **non-life insurance**, previously considered part of exempt financial services, has been **excluded** from list of exempt financial services under paragraph 19.

**Impact:**
- Persons supplying non-life insurance products now **required to account for tax** on their supplies
- With non-life insurance no longer exempt, providers may be **eligible to recover input tax**

**VAT Withholding Requirements:**
- GRA-appointed VAT-registered withholding agents must withhold **7%** of taxable value when making payments
- Due: 15th day of month following transaction
- Failure penalty: **30%** penalty on amount that should have been withheld

**Standard VAT Rate:**
- VAT: **15%**
- NHIL: **2.5%**
- GETFL: **2.5%**
- CHRL: **1%**

**Legal Framework:**
Goods and services exempt under VAT Act 2013 (Act 870) Section 15/Schedule 1. Also exempt from NHIL and GETFund.

---

### 2.3 TAX INCENTIVES FOR FINTECH/TECHNOLOGY COMPANIES

**SOURCE_URL:** https://taxsummaries.pwc.com/ghana/corporate/tax-credits-and-incentives
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Ghana
**CATEGORY:** Tax
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Tax Guide
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2024
**CONTENT:**

**ICT Sector Incentives:**
- **7-year tax exemption**
- Relief from double taxation for foreign investors and employees (if applicable)
- Ability to carry forward tax losses for **up to 5 years**

**Ghana Cash-Lite Roadmap (launched May 2020):**

Framework to introduce fiscal incentives for fintech companies:
- Tax holidays for fintechs
- Tax rebates for consumers
- Reduced taxes on smartphones, POS terminals, and payment cards

Government aims to incentivize digital payments by providing short-term income tax incentives for businesses adopting digital payment means.

**General Corporate Tax Incentives:**
- Exemption from customs import duties on plant and machinery
- Reduced CIT rates
- More favorable investment and capital allowances
- Reduction in actual CIT payable
- Retention of foreign exchange earnings
- Guaranteed free transfer of dividends or net profits
- Guarantees against expropriation by government

**Free Zone Incentives (Free Zone Act 1995):**
- **100% exemption** from direct and indirect duties/levies on imports for production and exports
- **100% exemption** from income tax on profits for **10 years**, rates not exceeding **8%** thereafter
- **Total exemption** from withholding taxes from dividends arising from free zone investments
- Relief from double taxation

**Location-Based Incentives:**
- Export of non-traditional products: **8%** concessionary tax rate
- Manufacturing plants outside Accra/Tema: **18.75%** CIT
- Manufacturing outside regional capitals: **12.50%** CIT

**Regulatory Environment 2024:**
- Nation at forefront of fintech innovation
- Regulatory sandbox established by Bank of Ghana
- 2024 Draft Digital Assets Guidelines demonstrate receptiveness to licensing digital assets
- BOG regularly invites sector players to regulatory sandbox (latest May 2024)

**E-Levy Consideration:**
Ghana has one of steepest and widest-ranging taxes on financial technology services in world. Tax applies to:
- Bank to mobile wallet
- Mobile wallet to bank
- Bank to bank transfers

### 2.4 WITHHOLDING TAX ON FOREIGN SOFTWARE PAYMENTS

**SOURCE_URL:** https://taxsummaries.pwc.com/ghana/corporate/withholding-taxes
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Ghana
**CATEGORY:** Tax
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Tax Summary
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2024
**CONTENT:**

**General Withholding Tax Rules for Non-Residents:**

Unless tax treaty provides otherwise, Ghana levies withholding tax on most payments to non-residents.

**Payments for Supply of Goods, Works or Services:**
- Standard rate: **20%** withholding tax
- Applies to: contracts with non-resident person for supply of goods, work, or services where contract gives rise to income in Ghana
- **This typically applies to foreign software payments as services**

**Resident person must:**
- Withhold tax for payments under contract with non-resident
- Within **30 days** of contract date, give notice to Commissioner-General

**Other Relevant Non-Resident Rates:**
- Communication business (transmitting/receiving messages by cable, radio, optical fiber, satellite, electronic communication): **15%** withholding tax

**Double Tax Treaties (DTAs):**
- Some DTAs provide **lower withholding tax rates** on passive income and technical service fees
- Apply to payments to non-residents
- Excluding payments connected to permanent establishment (PE) of non-resident in Ghana

**DTAs Signed but Not Yet in Force:**
Barbados, Iran, Luxembourg, Seychelles, United Arab Emirates (UAE)

**Government Pursuing DTAs with:**
China, Egypt, Hungary, Israel, Japan, Jersey, Nigeria, Portugal, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, South Korea, Sweden, Syria, Tunisia, Turkey

**Filing Requirements:**
- Withholding agent must file and pay Commissioner-General within **15 days** after end of month
- Statement in prescribed form + tax withheld
- Withholding agent who fails to withhold liable to pay tax
- Entitled to recover tax paid from withholdee

## 3. BANK OF GHANA REGULATIONS (6+ Documents)

### 3.1 MICROFINANCE LICENSING REQUIREMENTS

**SOURCE_URL:** https://www.bog.gov.gh/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/REQUIREMENT-FOR-MFI-LICENCE.pdf
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Ghana
**CATEGORY:** Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Licensing Guidelines
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2011 (Updated 2020)
**CONTENT:**

**Bank of Ghana Microfinance Regulatory Framework:**

Operating Rules and Guidelines for Microfinance Institutions in Ghana (Notice No. BG/GOV/SEC/2011/04, July 2011)

**Four-Tier Classification System:**

**Tier 1:**
- Rural and Community Banks
- Finance Houses
- Savings and Loans Companies

**Tier 2:** Deposit-Taking Microfinance Companies (MFCs)
- Minimum capital: **GH₵2.0 million**
- Supervised by: Other Financial Institutions Supervision Department (OFISD)

**Tier 3:** Micro-Credit Companies & FNGOs
- Micro-credit Companies minimum capital: **GH₵2.0 million**
- FNGOs minimum capital: **GH₵0.3 million**
- Supervised by: OFISD

**Tier 4:** Micro-Credit Institutions & Susu Collectors
- No minimum capital requirement
- Supervised by: Micro-credit Association Ghana and Ghana Cooperative Susu Collectors Association (on behalf of BoG)

**Eligibility Requirements:**

**For Tier 3 Microfinance Business:**
- Only **body corporate incorporated in Ghana** eligible to apply
- Must obtain license from Bank of Ghana before carrying on microfinance business
- Must be **limited liability company** (per Banks and Specialised Deposit-Taking Institutions Act 2016, Act 930)

**Shareholding Requirements:**

**Tier 2 Institutions (Deposit-Taking):**
- Shareholding restricted to **Ghanaians only**
- Includes: MFCs, Susu companies, deposit-taking profit-making FNGOs

**Tier 3 Institutions (Non-Deposit-Taking):**
- May be exclusively Ghanaian
- May be exclusively foreign
- May be jointly Ghanaian and foreign
- Foreign capital must be registered at Ghana Investment Promotion Centre
- Minimum **2 shareholders**, none holding less than **10%** of total shares
- BoG has right to request dilution of shareholding

**Application Process - Three-Pronged:**

1. **Written Application to:**
   Head, Other Financial Institutions Supervision Department
   Bank of Ghana, Accra

2. **Required Documents:**
   - True certified copy of Certificate of Incorporation
   - Company Regulations
   - Registered name must include "Microfinance", "Money Lending", or "FNGO"

3. **Approval-in-Principle:**
   - BoG may issue for **6 months** if satisfied applicant will operate with integrity, prudence, professional competence
   - Must demonstrate capacity to raise initial paid-up capital
   - **NOT a final license** - cannot commence operations until final approval

**Pre-Licensing Conditions for Final Approval:**
- Minimum paid-up capital raised
- Evidence of title deeds/lease agreements
- Approvals by relevant authorities
- Adequate business premises with proper staff operating areas
- Ventilation and lighting
- Security of premises including alarm systems, fire extinguishers, vaults/safes

**Recent Regulatory Actions:**
- BoG undertook resolution exercise for comprehensive cleanup
- Strengthened regulatory and supervisory oversight
- **Revoked licenses:** 347 MFCs, 39 MCCs, 23 Savings and Loans Companies and Finance Houses

### 3.2 DIGITAL FINANCIAL SERVICES POLICY

**SOURCE_URL:** https://mofep.gov.gh/sites/default/files/acts/Ghana_DFS_Policy.pdf
**RETRIEVED:** 2025-12-03
**COUNTRY:** Ghana
**CATEGORY:** Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE:** Policy Document
**CERTAINTY:** High
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT:** 2019
**CONTENT:**

**National Digital Financial Services Policy:**

**Vision:**
Resilient, inclusive and innovative DFS ecosystem in Ghana.

**Government of Ghana's Three Roles:**
1. **Policy enabler** for DFS
2. **Driver and user** of DFS products
3. **Beneficiary** of DFS through cost savings, revenue increase, and monetary policy transmission

**Ministry of Finance Role:**
Developed DFS Policy detailing specific actions Ghana can take to build vibrant and inclusive DFS ecosystem.

**Key Policy Actions:**
- Promote enabling environment for DFS
- Leverage opportunities from digital technologies
- Support competition, efficiency, innovation
- Advance financial inclusion within payment ecosystem

**National Payment Systems Strategic Plan (2019-2024):**

Sets forth policy direction and guidelines promoting enabling environment to develop Ghanaian payment and financial systems.

**Key Objectives:**
- Leverage opportunities provided by digital technologies
- Promote competition within payment ecosystem
- Drive efficiency and innovation
- Enhance financial inclusion

**Infrastructure Foundations:**
- Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) system
- Ghana Interbank Payment and Settlement System (GhIPSS)
- Interoperability between banks and mobile money
- Made digital transactions easier and safer

Sets requirements for:

- Financial stability
